channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [LOG4J2-1180] Logger cache does not account for message factory
item.description:
The Logger cache does not account for a logger's message factory.

If you call LogManager.getLogger(Class|Object|String, MessageFactory) and then call a getLogger() API again with the same Class|Object|String a different message factory, you get the Logger that was first created which means you will not get the proper formatted messages.

For example:

Logger loggerA1 = LogManager.getLogger("A", messageFactory1);
Logger loggerA2 = LogManager.getLogger("A", messageFactory2);

loggerA1 is the same as loggerA2.

This is a problem if two unrelated code bases (jars) both the same Logger names|objects|classes.
item.summary: Logger cache does not account for message factory

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Patch but unit tests have not been adjusted.

This patch feels hacky because the internal key is now Name.FQCN_of_MessageFactory.

Perhaps we need a special Key class to make this cleaner.

Any thoughts here?

It seems weird to make the key more complicated, but how else would you deal with this case?

I have concerns that this patch is going to cause problems. You have effectively changed the name of the logger to include the messageFactory so %C is going to print the wrong thing. However, I think you should still end up with the correct LoggerConfig, but less efficiently since there will be a much longer name to parse.

Saving the Logger in the map and including the FQCN could be OK, so long as it isn't included in the logger name itself.

Hi Ralph,

Confused: %C picks up a stack element's class name. Do you mean a different % name?

Saving the Logger in the map and including the FQCN could be OK, so long as it isn't included in the logger name itself.

Do you mean something like having a Key class with a Logger name and MessageFactory as ivars? And using this Key class as the key instead of String?

Or do you mean using the logger as the key but instead of a Logger value, use a map of MessageFactory name to Logger?

I could see that as working, it's a two step process but O(1) + O(1) is still O(1).

Sorry, I meant %c not %C.

What I mean is that it would be OK to store the Logger in the Map using a key that concatenates the MessageFactory FQCN to the logger name, but that the Logger name itself must continue to just be the logger name (without the MessageFactory FQCN). You would then end up with multiple Loggers that have the same name but that is OK.
The patch uses a "key" lvar for key access and a "name" param for the logger name, so the patch is OK I think. Check?
In Git master.
Resloving, in Git master. mikael.staldal@home.se: Please verify and close.

In LoggerContext.java and SimpleLoggerContext.java:

        // The loggers map key is the logger name plus the messageFactory FQCN (if any).
        String key = name;
        if (messageFactory != null) {
            key = LoggerContextKey.create(name, messageFactory);
        }

Shouldn't this be:

        String key;
        if (messageFactory != null) {
            key = LoggerContextKey.create(name, messageFactory);
        } else {
            key = LoggerContextKey.create(name);
        }
It seems to work though.

There were some inefficiencies or even 'bugs' if you want to call them that, which I addressed. Can you please review the changes?

Thank you,
Gary

Looks OK, but is this comment (in LoggerContext.java and SimpleLoggerContext.java) accurate?

// The loggers map key is the logger name plus the messageFactory FQCN (if any).
Seems to work fine.
Good catch, thank you, fixed in Git master.
Closing, reporter on ML comments that it works fine.

Reopening for a potential issue I found while working on this area to address LOG4J2-1318:

garydgregory, ralph.goers@dslextreme.com, mikaelstaldal can you take a look at SLF4JLoggerContext? It looks like the getLogger(String, MessageFactory) method currently ignores the MessageFactory, and when I try to fix that in the spirit of LOG4J2-1180, the test in log4j-to-slf4j org.a.l.slf4j.LoggerTest breaks... (getLogger_String_MessageFactoryMismatchNull and getLogger_String_MessageFactoryMismatch)

Is there something special about SLF4J Loggers that they must be unique by name only, not by name/MessageFactory? Or are the current implementation and the test simply wrong - LOG4J2-1180 was not addressed correctly here?

Looking further, SLF4JLoggerContext is implemented a bit differently from the other LoggerContext implementations (SimpleLoggerContext, log4j-core LoggerContext and Log4jTaglibLoggerContext): the others all check if the previously registered logger matches the MessageFactory by calling AbstractLogger.checkMessageFactory(logger, messageFactory), but SLF4JLoggerContext does not.

Same question: is this a bug or is SLF4JLoggerContext special for some reason and is this difference by design?

Hello,

Since upgrading to 2.6 (from 2.5), I am now getting this message in the console (tomcat):

MyClass was created with the message factory org.apache.logging.log4j.spi.MessageFactory2Adapter@796e8a0f and is now requested with a null message factory (defaults to org.apache.logging.log4j.message.ParameterizedMessageFactory), which may create log events with unexpected formatting.

I am using org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory bridge with these jars

log4j-1.2-api-2.5.jar
log4j-api-2.5.jar
log4j-core-2.5.jar
log4j-jcl-2.5.jar
log4j-slf4j-impl-2.5.jar

Not sure if it relates to this patch, but if it does any ideas how to resolve the message?

Cheers
I am getting the same problem and I reverted to 2.5 until I can take the time to figure out what is happening.... unless someone else gets to it first....

I don't know if this has anything to do with the problem, but LoggerRegistry.getOrCreateInnerMap is not thread-safe. It should be using putIfAbsent but if it does it will break the WeakMapFactory since that doesn't use a ConcurrentMap.

I am also having a hard time understanding how this message is even possible. First we obtain a logger from the registry using the logger name and message factory as keys. Then we call AbstractLogger.checkMessageFactgory to verify that the Logger returned has the same factory as what was requested. Under what circumstances would the LoggerRegistry return a Logger using a different MessageFactory?
Without looking at the code, this may happen because we wrap legacy message factories in a MessageFactory2Adapter to support unrolled vararg methods.
Arg, shouldn't our buikt in guys not need a wrapper? (Phone)
(Again without looking at the code) yes, that may fix this issue.
I have a patch in progress for this but I have to be AFK for a few hours...

I believe it may be sufficient to get the original message factory from the MessageFactory2Adapter before verifying:

Index: log4j-api/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/spi/AbstractLogger.java
IDEA additional info:
Subsystem: com.intellij.openapi.diff.impl.patch.CharsetEP
<+>UTF-8
===================================================================
--- log4j-api/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/spi/AbstractLogger.java	(revision )
+++ log4j-api/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/spi/AbstractLogger.java	(revision )
@@ -136,7 +136,10 @@
      */
     public static void checkMessageFactory(final ExtendedLogger logger, final MessageFactory messageFactory) {
         final String name = logger.getName();
-        final MessageFactory loggerMessageFactory = logger.getMessageFactory();
+        MessageFactory loggerMessageFactory = logger.getMessageFactory();
+        if (loggerMessageFactory instanceof MessageFactory2Adapter) {
+            loggerMessageFactory = ((MessageFactory2Adapter) loggerMessageFactory).getOriginal();
+        }
         if (messageFactory != null && !loggerMessageFactory.equals(messageFactory)) {
             StatusLogger.getLogger().warn(
                     "The Logger {} was created with the message factory {} and is now requested with the "
That might be enough to fix the problem but I believe the proper solution is to implement MessageFactory2, it just seems like it was an oversight. See attached (tests pass).
I think I deliberately did not do implement MessageFactory2 on the existing factories to avoid binary compatibility issues for people extending our existing factories. The adapter solves this.
That seems odd. This means that the factories cannot optimally implement message creation as each sees fit. The patch I have attached would also handle BC.
Okay. My main concern is to avoid breaking client code. If there is no risk there then I'm fine with implementing MessageFactory2 on the existing built-in factories.
See linked ticket.

garydgregory, ralph.goers@dslextreme.com, mikaelstaldal can you take a look at SLF4JLoggerContext? It looks like the getLogger(String, MessageFactory) method currently ignores the MessageFactory, and when I try to fix that in the spirit of LOG4J2-1180, the test in log4j-to-slf4j org.a.l.slf4j.LoggerTest breaks... (getLogger_String_MessageFactoryMismatchNull and getLogger_String_MessageFactoryMismatch) Is there something special about SLF4J Loggers that they must be unique by name only, not by name/MessageFactory? Or are the current implementation and the test simply wrong - LOG4J2-1180 was not addressed correctly here?

https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/pull/651/ fixes this FYI.
https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/pull/651/ was FYI a result of my staring at that code in the context of LOG4J2-3282.
